body: For instance, you get a bunch of smooth brain corporate leftists like many NBA basketball players and others who try to preach BLM to you but once you mention the Hong Kong protesters or Free Hong Kong and point out how they're blatantly selective with their "social justice", they will get low-key defensive of the CCP and cry "This is whataboutism!" to deflect from getting called out for their hypocrisy.

title: Why do people on the political left love to always pull the "whataboutism" card whenever they get called out for their abundant hypocrisy?

body:
Because partisans *constantly* ignore all their own flaws by pointing their finger at something else.

Partisanship is the belief that it's fine to be a huge piece of shit as long as someone on the other side of the fence is an equally huge piece of shit. It's a race to the bottom.

The left isn't wrong - they're just blind to the fact that they do exactly the same thing.

It is impossible to be both partisan and principled.

It is impossible to be both partisan and principled.

body:
https://odysee.com/@lotuseaters_com:1/free-speech-is-dangerous-to-the-left:3

Watch this video and all the way through if you have the time because it's a fascinating insight into why they do this. When they ignore something that counters their narrative or try to dismiss it it's a tactic, they do it because they know they've lost the argument and this woman that this insufferable left wing guardian activist called Owen Jones just nodding along with just came out and said it. Take for example the issue of fishing rights in the UK which is directly tied to independent sovereignty if we want to preserve that, she actually dismisses it as a 'red herring' which just means she doesn't like talking about that so they just switch over to something else.

It's a really fucking weak playbook yet it's amazing how often they use it and how many people fall for it. It's also the standard tactic of any extremist as well, when they can't switch the topic then they'll make it personal and try to go after you specifically and make it all about you and it's because we're talking about issues that make them uncomfortable or make them look bad. Oh and yes I will call these people extremists because if they're the sort of person who tries to smear and destroy someone's life just because they bring up a topic then that is extremists because honest people would simply admit they might have a point. You have to remember that you're not-so-average person who spergs out on social media about anti-capitalism is often an activist and not genuine in the slightest and they of course infest places like reddit and twitter so they'll operate from the social justice playbook to a tee. Once you figure that out then they actually become incredibly easy to deal with.

You brought up Hong Kong and that's a very good point because you'd think these morons would immediately side with them but because they have CCP masters and likely take money from them they immediately go quiet. As a result I've decided I'm going to show people exactly how to deal with the left and I'm going to bring up Taiwan as an issue which you may even hear about in the coming months depending on how much traction I get if they don't just ignore me outright. In order to beat these people you don't simply go along with their bullshit where they switch subjects because they don't like it, you hammer them on these specific points until they break, but people are too fucking nice and they get away with it every time even with people who should know better about these lot.

Left wingers should absolutely be in support of Taiwan being independent and so on, but watch them crumble at the mere mention of it, I bet there will even be media who won't even mention the name and I'm going to exploit the fuck out of that.

post.title: Why do people on the political left love to always pull the "whataboutism" card whenever they get called out for their abundant hypocrisy?

body:
The accusation of whataboutism can sometimes be valid. For instance, the Soviet Union would often deflect accusations of human rights violations by bringing up injustices in western countries e.g. racism in the USA. They would dodge criticism for their own actions by saying 'what about how the USA lynches blacks?'. Obviously this is just a disingenuous way of avoiding criticism. If someone tries to dodge criticism with theirown criticism, it is valid to point it out.

However, when leftists accuse the right of whataboutism, it's because they don't understand that we are not dodging criticism, but pointing out double standards which refute the original criticism. Typically what happens is some right winger does something, and the left accuses them of racism, sexism or some other thought crime. When the right points out left-wingers doing the exact same thing, the only response the left has is to cry 'that's whataboutism though'. What they misunderstand however, is that pointing out a left winger doing the exact same thing isn't an attempt to dodge criticism. It's pointing out that standards are being applied differently to people on the right, that the left is being hypocritical. I.e. pointing out the double standard proves that the reason the right winger is being criticised isn't because of what they did, it's just because they're right wing. 

Take the example of Gina Carano being fired from The Mandalorian. She made a post comparing conservatives to jews, and the establishment left to nazis circa 1933, when the nazis made the germans hate the jews so much the people would be happy for the jews to be persecuted. Apparently this is antisemitic, somehow, according to the establishment left. But her co-star Pedro Pascal makes a post comparing illegal immigrant children being incarcerated by ICE to jews being persecuted by by the nazis, and he doesn't get any punishment for it. Pointing this out isn't saying 'oh I know Gina did something wrong, but what about Pedro Pascal!' It's pointing out that other people who weren't conservative said similar things and weren't accused of antisemitism. When Gina was accused of antisemitism, it clearly had nothing to do with the content of her post, it was because she's a conservative.

The accusation of whataboutism can sometimes be valid. For instance, the Soviet Union would often deflect accusations of human rights violations by bringing up injustices in western countries e.g. racism in the USA. They would dodge criticism for their own actions by saying 'what about how the USA lynches blacks?'. Obviously this is just a disingenuous way of avoiding criticism. If someone tries to dodge criticism with theirown criticism, it is valid to point it out.

However, when leftists accuse the right of whataboutism, it's because they don't understand that we are not dodging criticism, but pointing out double standards which refute the original criticism. Typically what happens is some right winger does something, and the left accuses them of racism, sexism or some other thought crime. When the right points out left-wingers doing the exact same thing, the only response the left has is to cry 'that's whataboutism though'. What they misunderstand however, is that pointing out a left winger doing the exact same thing isn't an attempt to dodge criticism. It's pointing out that standards are being applied differently to people on the right, that the left is being hypocritical. I.e. pointing out the double standard proves that the reason the right winger is being criticised isn't because of what they did, it's just because they're right wing.

Take the example of Gina Carano being fired from The Mandalorian. She made a post comparing conservatives to jews, and the establishment left to nazis circa 1933, when the nazis made the germans hate the jews so much the people would be happy for the jews to be persecuted. Apparently this is antisemitic, somehow, according to the establishment left. But her co-star Pedro Pascal makes a post comparing illegal immigrant children being incarcerated by ICE to jews being persecuted by by the nazis, and he doesn't get any punishment for it. Pointing this out isn't saying 'oh I know Gina did something wrong, but what about Pedro Pascal!' It's pointing out that other people who weren't conservative said similar things and weren't accused of antisemitism. When Gina was accused of antisemitism, it clearly had nothing to do with the content of her post, it was because she's a conservative.

body: I've debated thousands of them for years (i used to be a New Atheist, but still extremely skeptical of the left). Leftists essentially don't have any sort of narrative, most leftists are just trying to exploit their faux-identitarianism for social standing or are so scared by the "PULL YOURSELF BY THE BOOTSTRAPS" narrative that they started to believe that even a basic tax increase is the epitome of socialism. If you don't have a narrative, you can't essentially debate. Morgoth Review has a series of videos on leftist "archetypes", that you might want to watch, because it's extremely descriptive of them.
